workflow.header:
From passive media consumption
to active, deliberate practice.
workflow.intro: Y'ALL Media Player is a specialized tool designed for immersion learning. It seamlessly integrates video playback, subtitle management, dictionary lookups, and Anki flashcard creation into a single workflow, optimizing the time spent learning native content:
workflow.step1: Open any media file with subtitles in the same target language (e.g., Italian movie with Italian subtitles). Subtitles can be either embedded or from an external file.
workflow.step2: The player automatically parses the subtitles and transforms them into a series of clips, presented on an interactive timeline, that you can edit on the fly.
workflow.step3: The timeline distinguishes between segments with dialogue (subtitled clips) and those without (gaps). You can configure different behaviors - such as playback speed or auto-pausing - for each type separately.
workflow.step4: Select a configuration preset based on your current goal - e.g., listening comprehension or pronunciation - or customize every setting to fit your personal workflow.
workflow.step5: Hover over unknown words to check their definition instantly via offline dictionaries, or click to search online for context.

feature_timeline.title: Interactive timeline
feature_timeline.desc:
Most media players just render static text on top of a video and call it a day.
Y'ALL Media Player gives you full control over its dynamic, interactive timeline:
list: Visualize audio: Enable waveform visualization in global settings to see peaks and silence. Know exactly when a sentence begins and ends.
Adjust timing: Subtitles out of sync? Simply drag the edges of a clip on the timeline to fix start and end times instantly.
Edit on the fly: Change the text of subtitles, or add your own, directly in the app.
Split & merge: Fix broken sentence parsing by splitting long clips or merging fragmented ones.
Multi-track support: Easily access and manage parallel tracks found in advanced subtitle formats like ASS/SSA.

feature_playback.title: Optimized playback
feature_playback.desc_html:
Don't waste your time watching scenery - focus on the dialogue.
Y'ALL Media Player treats media as a consecutive playlist of two distinct clip types: Subtitled Clips and Gaps between them.

Increase the Gaps speed to fast-forward the silence automatically and get faster to Subtitled Clips which can be played at normal speed. You can also skip the Gaps altogether and just jump to the nearest Subtitled Clip.

Transform a ~40-minute episode into ~30 minutes of pure, high-density input.

feature_dict.title: Instant dictionary lookups
feature_dict.desc: Stop Alt-Tabbing to a web browser and breaking your immersion:
list: Zero-latency popups: Hover over any word to instantly see its definition in the offline dictionary powered by bundled Yomitan extension.
Online lookup: Click on any word to instantly open the built-in browser with your preferred preconfigured website.
Smart tokenization: Advanced word boundary detection allows precise selection of words or phrases, even for languages without spaces like Japanese.
Precise control: Hold CTRL to select specific characters or click-and-drag to select entire phrases.

Zero-friction notes: Highlight a word definition in the built-in browser or offline popup and save it directly to your card notes via the right-click context menu or a keyboard shortcut (CTRL+SHIFT+S) - no tedious copy-pasting required.
feature_dict.note: Click here for detailed offline dictionary setup guide →

feature_anki.title: Anki integration
feature_anki.desc_html:
Found a sentence worth remembering? Press E to export it to Anki and remember it forever.

The player automatically extracts the audio, captures a screenshot, looped animation or entire video clip, grabs the text with your notes, and sends a high-quality flashcard directly to Anki via AnkiConnect.

Click here for detailed Anki integration instructions →

feature_presets.title: Settings presets
feature_presets.desc: Use one of the learning modes for immediate feedback, which helps quickly correct mistakes, reinforce learning, and deepen understanding, making learning active and improving outcomes significantly, based on your current goals:
list: Listening practice: Auto-hides subtitles until you toggle them, then auto-pauses the clip at the end, allowing you to verify first what you heard, before revealing the subtitles.
Speaking practice: Auto-pauses at the start of a clip, letting you read the text before resuming the clip and comparing your pronunciation with the native audio.
Custom: Tweak every setting to create your own ideal configuration.

feature_progress.title: Progress tracking
feature_progress.desc_html:
Every media file is treated as a separate project. The app remembers last playback position, timeline adjustments, and your manual notes, so you can pick up exactly where you left off and track progress.

This transforms media from a fleeting stream of content into a concrete list of sentences to be learned.

faq.q: Why do I see a warning on Windows when trying to install the app?
faq.a:
All new versions of Y'ALL Media Player are automatically submitted to Microsoft for security verification. However, building "reputation" for a new installer takes time.

If you see a blue window with "Windows protected your PC" warning when trying to install, it simply means you are one of the first people to try a freshly released version that hasn't completed this verification process yet.

Here are possible solutions:
1. Wait: You can try again later. Usually, the verification process takes up to 24 hours from release.
2. Install anyway: You can safely ignore the warning, because it is a false positive - the app is open source and safe.
Just click More Info → Run Anyway.
3. Use previous version: You can visit the GitHub page and install an older version (look for file with .exe extension) which is guaranteed to be verified already.

faq.q: How do I report a bug, request a feature or post constructive criticism?
faq.a:
Feedback is very welcome! This is an open source project developed by one person, so your input helps a lot.

You can send me an email directly or, if you have a GitHub account, you can open a new issue in the repository.

faq.q: Why can't I see the audio waveform on the timeline?
faq.a:
Audio waveform generation is a performance-heavy process that takes a long time once per project (around ~1 minute for ~2h video on a high-end computer).
During that time, while the timeline is being generated, the video playback is unavailable.

Because of that, and for performance reasons, it's disabled by default.
You can enable it manually in the global settings inside the app.

faq.q: How do I set up Anki integration?
faq.a:
Y'ALL Media Player connects seamlessly with Anki via the AnkiConnect add-on.
You can create cards with text, audio, screenshots, and video clips in one click.
Click here for detailed Anki integration instructions →

faq.q: How do I configure offline dictionaries?
faq.a:
Y'ALL Media Player comes with the Yomitan browser extension bundled in.
You can configure installed dictionaries, handle complex languages (like Japanese or Chinese), etc. in the global settings.
Click here for detailed dictionary setup guide →
Yes - the source code is available on GitHub under the GPLv3 license.

Yes - after initial configuration and installation of offline dictionaries.
Video playback, timeline editing, Anki export, and dictionary lookups (via Yomitan) work fully offline.
Online lookups naturally require an internet connection, but they are optional.

faq.q: Is streaming from platforms like Youtube supported?
faq.a: No, sorry. Only local files are supported, because their entire content needs to be known upfront for all the features to work properly. There are many services online which let your download videos with subtitles from Youtube etc., so you should never run out of the content to watch!

faq.q: Why is the playback stuttering sometimes?
faq.a:
Y'ALL Media Player isn't designed for regular, continuous playback of media, like conventional media players.

Instead, it creates a playlist of clips, that are played on by one, with different settings, depending whether they have subtitles or not.

The moment of switching clips takes time, which may seem like stuttering, but it's negligible once you start using one of the preconfigured learning modes (listening or speaking practice), because they auto-pause after each subtitled clip, awaiting for your explicit action to continue playback.

anki.intro: Anki is a flashcard program that helps you spend more time on challenging material, and less on what you already know.
anki.step1: Install Anki on your computer and log in with your free account.
anki.step2: Install the AnkiConnect add-on in Anki. After installation, restart Anki for the changes to take effect. Verify that it was installed properly by visiting the localhost:8765 address in the browser. You should see something similar to {"apiVersion": "AnkiConnect v.6"}
anki.step3: Create new deck in Anki ("Create Deck" at the bottom of the page) and name it accordingly (e.g., "English pronunciation", "Spanish sentence cards" etc.). Configuring specific deck options is beyond the scope of this manual - check official Anki documentation for that - but you should be fine with default settings for now.
anki.step4_intro: In Anki, select "Tools" -> "Manage Note Types" from the menu:
anki.step4_list_2: â€¢ Click "OK" with option "Add: Basic" selected.
anki.step4_list_3: â€¢ Give your card template some name, for example "yall-mp", confirm.
anki.step4_list_4: â€¢ The note will appear on the list of note types:
anki.step4_img_alt: New note type on the list
anki.step5_intro: With the new note type highlighted (just like in the screenshot above), click on the "Fields" button - new dialog window will appear:
anki.step5_list_1: â€¢ Here you can configure fields for different elements that Y'ALL Media Player can export.
anki.step5_list_2: â€¢ You need a separate field for "id" and at least 1 field out of: "subtitle_text", "audio", "screenshot", "video_clip", "animation", "notes".
anki.step5_list_3: â€¢ You can remove the default "Front" and "Back" fields.
anki.step5_list_4: â€¢ You should end up with something like this:
anki.step5_img_alt: List of fields for note type
anki.step5_note_1: Here I am using all the fields available, but you don't have to define them all. If you are 100% sure you won't need video clip for example, you can omit the "video_clip" field etc. Keep in mind that "id" field and at least 1 other, from the list above, are required later to integrate properly.
anki.step5_note_2: â€¢ After adding all the fields that you need, click "Save" to exit the "Fields" dialog and go back to "Note Types" dialog.
anki.step6_intro: Now for the final step, make sure your new note type is still selected, then click on "Cards" button:
anki.step6_list_1: â€¢ Here, you can configure the "front" and "back" of your flashcard - which of the configured fields will be displayed where etc.
anki.step6_list_2: â€¢ You can define any HTML and CSS you want, but for simplicity we will create the most barebone card template possible.
anki.step6_list_3: â€¢ It all depends what type of card you want to achieve. Y'ALL Media Player supports exporting multiple flashcard types at once, so you can define as many card templates as you want.
anki.step6_list_4: â€¢ To keep it simple, let's assume you want a card for listening comprehension - "audio" on the front, "subtitle_text" on the back.
anki.step6_list_5: â€¢ Select "Front Template" radio button (should be selected by default) and put the code "{{audio}}" in the large textarea below it:
anki.step6_img_alt_1: Defining the front side of Anki card template
anki.step6_mid_text: â€¢ Now select "Back Template" radio button and put the following code in the large textarea below it:
anki.step6_img_alt_2: Defining the back side of Anki card template
anki.step6_end_1: â€¢ Click "Save" to confirm and exit the dialog, then also close the "Note Types" dialog.
anki.step6_end_2: â€¢ That is of course the simplest card template you could possibly make - to learn more, consult the official Anki documentation.
anki.step6_end_3: â€¢ Add as many card templates as you need - for example you might want a separate template for reading comprehension (text on the front, audio on the back) etc.
anki.step7: Always keep Anki open in the background when using Y'ALL Media Player. It will be automatically detected by the app.
anki.step8: In Y'ALL Media Player, open global settings from the main menu (keyboard shortcut: O), go to the "Anki integration" tab and configure new Anki template(s) - you should be able to see your Anki deck, created note type etc.:
anki.step8_img_alt: Defining new Anki card template in Y'ALL Media Player
anki.step9: Everything should work now. Play some subtitled clip and either press E keyboard shortcut or right click the clip on the timeline and select "Export to Anki". Remember to select the card template(s) you want to use and press Export:
anki.step9_img_alt: Anki export dialog in Y'ALL Media Player

dicts.intro: Yomitan is a browser extension that provides dictionary definitions in popup window when hovering over text.
dicts.step1: Open Y'ALL Media Player and go to main menu -> "Global settings " (or press O keyboard shortcut).
dicts.step2: Go to the Offline Dictionaries tab.
dicts.step3: Important: offline dictionaries are configured separately for each language. First, select your target language from the dropdown at the top of the page:
dicts.step3_img_alt: "Offline Dictionaries" tab with language selection dropdown
dicts.step4: Once you select a language, the easiest way to add a dictionary for it is to click "Get recommended dictionaries..." and then "Download" next to one of the recommended dictionaries in the dialog window. You can install multiple dictionaries for a single language (if available), because some of them serve different purposes (e.g., there's a separate dictionary for kanji stroke order in Japanese). Wait several minutes for the selected dictionary to finish downloading and importing, then close the global settings dialog window.
dicts.step5: Alternatively, advanced users can also download dictionaries from sources like the Kaikki project and import them from a file using the "Configure installed and enabled dictionaries..." -> "Import" buttons. Dictionaries must be in Yomitan or Yomichan format. Legacy formats like EPWING etc. must first be converted using the official Yomitan importer.
dicts.step6: Final step: open a project, go to the project settings (keyboard shortcut P) and ensure the correct language is set in the "Subtitles Language Detection" section. This connects your project to the dictionaries you've configured for that language. After that you can close the project specific settings panel.
dicts.step6_img_alt: Current project settings with "Subtitles Language Detection" section
dicts.step7: That's it! You should now be able to hover over text in subtitles and see a popup with dictionary definition in it. For more information regarding advanced Yomitan configuration, visit the official Yomitan webpage.
dicts.step7_img_alt: Offline dictionary popup on subtitles hover
